pages.text: Parapuzosia was a large ammonite that lived during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 70-66 million years ago. Growing up to 2 meters in diameter, this prehistoric cephalopod was characterized by its distinctive coiled shell and tentacles. Parapuzosia inhabited warm, shallow seas and was a predator, feeding primarily on small fish and crustaceans. Fossil remains have been found in various locations around the world, including North America, Europe, and Africa.
Imagine a snail the size of a car tire - that's basically what this ancient mollusk was
